caption:
Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado won the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for promoting democratic rights in her country and her struggle to achieve a transition to democracy, the Norwegian Nobel Committee said.
 
The committee chose to focus on Venezuela at this time, in a year dominated by U.S. President Donald Trump’s repeated public statements that he deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.
 
Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado won the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for promoting democratic rights in her country and her struggle to achieve a transition to democracy, the Norwegian Nobel Committee said.
 
The committee chose to focus on Venezuela at this time, in a year dominated by U.S. President Donald Trump’s repeated public statements that he deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.
 
🔗 Read about her work at our link in bio

Canada’s Marineland theme park, which closed last year, says it may have to euthanize its remaining 30 beluga whales if they don’t receive emergency funding from the government. 

#funding #whales #beluga #themepark #marineland

Israeli tanks were seen firing on a crowded coastal path near Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip shortly after a ceasefire and hostage deal were announced. Reuters footage showed explosions and smoke from tank shelling on an area close to where dozens of Palestinians were walking.
 
🔗 Read more at our link in bio.

Emergency personnel blasted sirens in Gaza City as they chanted in celebration, after a ceasefire and hostage deal was announced under the first phase of U.S. President Donald Trump’s initiative to end the war in Gaza. Palestinians in Deir al-Balah also celebrated by shooting celebratory gunfire.
 
🔗 Read more at our link in bio.

A displaced Palestinian child looks through a covering made from blankets as they take shelter at an UNRWA-run school in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, October 9, 2025. 

Israelis and Palestinians rejoiced after a ceasefire and hostage deal was announced, under the first phase of President Donald Trump’s initiative to end the war in Gaza which has killed tens of thousands and reshaped the Middle East. 

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Ramadan Abed

Former hostages and families of those still held in Gaza celebrated at Tel Aviv’s Hostages Square in the early hours of October 9 after reports of the agreement signed between Israel and Hamas, to end the war in Gaza and return all the Israeli hostages, both living and deceased, home.
 
#gaza #ceasefire #israel #hamas

Palestinians in Khan Younis took to the streets in celebration on October 9 after Israel and Hamas agreed to the first phase of President Donald Trump’s plan to end the Gaza war. 🔗 Read more about the ceasefire at the link in our bio.

Donald Trump's threat to invoke an anti-insurrection law and deploy troops to more U.S. cities intensified the battle over the limits to his authority.
 
The Republican president on October 7 again left open the possibility that he might use the centuries-old Insurrection Act to sidestep any court rulings blocking the dispatch of Guard troops into Democratic-led cities, over the objections of local and state officials. 🔗 Read more about what this means at the link in our bio.

A girl walks through an installation of flowers at the site of the Nova festival where partygoers were killed and kidnapped, on the two-year anniversary of the deadly October 7, 2023 attack on Israel by Hamas from Gaza, in Reim, southern Israel, October 7, 2025.
 
Hamas said it wants to reach a deal to end the war in Gaza based on U.S. President Trump's plan, but still has a set of demands, signaling that indirect talks with Israel in Egypt could be difficult and lengthy.
 
Senior Hamas official Fawzi Barhoum set out Hamas' position on the second anniversary of the attack, and one day after the indirect negotiations began in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt.
 
The talks appear the most promising yet for ending a war that has killed tens of thousands of Palestinians and devastated Gaza since the October 7, 2023 attack on Israel, in which 1,200 people were killed and 251 were taken back to Gaza as hostages.
 
🔗 Read the latest at our link in bio. 📷 Itay Cohen

Demonstrators wearing inflatable animal costumes participate in a protest outside the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement headquarters in south Portland, Oregon, October 6, 2025, as law-enforcement officers work to disperse the crowd to clear traffic to the building. 
 
President Trump claimed without evidence during an interview on Newsmax that an insurrection is taking place in the city as he seeks to deploy National Guard troops amid what he describes as surging crime. 
 
🔗 Read the latest at our link in bio. 📷 @CarlosaBarria
The first Supermoon of the year, known as the Harvest Moon, rises above the Mario Cuomo Bridge spanning the Hudson River as seen from Grandview, New York, October 6, 2025. 📷 @msegar

Swedish activist Greta Thunberg walks through Ramon International Airport before her deportation flight, near Eilat, Israel, October 6, 2025, after Israel intercepted the vessels of the Global Sumud Flotilla aiming to reach Gaza to break Israel’s naval blockade. 

Israel said it deported campaigner Greta Thunberg and another 170 activists from the flotilla, sending them to Greece and Slovakia.

Earlier, Swiss and Spanish activists from the flotilla said they were subjected to inhumane conditions during their detention by Israeli forces. Monday’s expulsions brought to 341 the total number deported from 479 detained.

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Israel Foreign Ministry

France’s new Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu and his government resigned on October 6, hours after Lecornu announced his cabinet line-up, making it the shortest-lived cabinet in modern French history, driving stocks and the euro sharply lower. 🔗 Read more at the link in bio.

Meet Steve Simoni, a Silicon Valley nerd who’s pivoting from QR codes to AI-powered, drone-killing machine guns. ‘I’m a warlord now, b***h!’ he says, only partly in jest. Simoni is part of a new generation of tech entrepreneurs trying to reinvent warfare and the Pentagon. 🔗 Read more at the link in bio.

Sean “Diddy” Combs becomes emotional as his children go to the podium to make impact statements, and his children are shown as babies on a screen, during his court sentencing in New York City, October 3, 2025. 

Combs apologized to his former girlfriend Casandra Ventura on Friday at the hip-hop mogul’s sentencing over prostitution charges.

Jurors at Combs’ trial were shown video of him assaulting Ventura, a singer known professionally as Cassie.

🔗 Read the latest on the trial at our link in bio.  🎨 Jane Rosenberg

Police officers run away from flames as demonstrators clash with police officers during a march to mark the 57th anniversary of the 1968 Tlatelolco Square massacre, in which students were shot dead by the military, in Mexico City, October 2, 2025. 📷 @henryromerohr

The human-trafficking victims forced to scam strangers
 
Across Southeast Asia, a multibillion-dollar fraud industry is staffed in part through compounds run by Chinese criminal gangs, which contain thousands of people forced to scam strangers online or face punishment. 
 
Thailand has become a key transit hub for trafficking victims. Some have been escorted through Bangkok’s two international airports by presumed immigration officials before being spirited away to Myanmar by car.
 
Reuters spoke to people held against their will, who described the brutal conditions inside the centers. 

🔗 Read more at the link in bio.

Foreign aid cuts by the U.S., particularly the President's Malaria Initiative, which was launched in 2005 by George W. Bush, have led to significant disruptions in malaria prevention and treatment efforts in Cameroon and other African countries. This has resulted in a rise in malaria fatalities, as community health workers funded by the U.S. are no longer operational, and essential drugs like injectable artesunate are in short supply. 

🔗 Read more at the link in bio

At least two people were killed after an assailant reportedly drove a car into pedestrians and stabbed a security guard near a synagogue in Manchester in northwest England on October 2, British police said, adding that officers had shot the suspect. Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the incident was "absolutely shocking" and that police were being deployed to synagogues across the country.

🔗 Read more about the attack and the authorities' response at our link in bio

People gather near the scene of an attack near a synagogue in north Manchester, England, October 2, 2025.  
 
Two people were killed after an assailant drove a car into pedestrians and stabbed a security guard near a synagogue on Yom Kippur, the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, British police said. 
 
Greater Manchester Police said officers had shot the suspect after being called to the scene at the Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation Synagogue in the Crumpsall district of the city in northern England. 
 
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @philnoblepix

Protesters rallied in cities from Turkey to Argentina on October 1, after Israeli forces intercepted a Gaza aid flotilla, with demonstrators voicing support for the mission and calling for the release of detained crew members.

🔗 Italian unions also called a general strike on October 3 in solidarity. Read more at our link in bio

Scientist and global activist Jane Goodall, who turned her childhood love of primates into a lifelong quest for protecting the environment, died at the age of 91, the institute she founded said.
 
Goodall was a pioneer in her field, both as a female scientist in the 1960s and for her work studying the behavior of primates. She created a path for a string of other women to follow suit, including the late Dian Fossey.
 
🔗 Read the full obituary at our link in bio.

A Palestinian girl sits among debris at a United Nations school where displaced people were taking shelter after it was hit in overnight Israeli strikes in Gaza City, October 1, 2025.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s support for Donald Trump’s Gaza plan is a gamble that may win back estranged allies abroad and repair his political base at home but risks a battle with coalition partners opposed to any hint of a Palestinian state.
Netanyahu, aligning himself with Trump, framed the plan as a joint effort that advances his government's goals while shifting international criticism about the war onto Hamas, which must now choose between accepting it or facing continued siege.
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Ebrahim Hajjaj

The international flotilla trying to deliver aid to Gaza continued its journey on October 1, as a live feed from the participating boats showed. "We have now entered the high-risk zone, the area where previous flotillas have been attacked and/or intercepted," the Global Sumud Flotilla said in a post on Telegram.

🔗 Read the latest at our link in bio

Torrential rains from storm Gabrielle submerged dozens of vehicles and stopped some ferries from docking on the Mediterranean island of Ibiza. Travelers were seen clambering out into streets that had turned into muddy rivers.

EXCLUSIVE: Pop Mart is adopting a strategy similar to Disney’s by focusing on long-term intellectual-property management to capitalize on the success of its toy character Labubu.
 
The company aims to develop content, entertainment, theme parks, and merchandise around Labubu, similar to how Disney manages its popular IPs like Mickey Mouse.
 
🔗 Read executive director and co-COO Si De’s exclusive Reuters interview at the link in bio.

EXCLUSIVE: US federal drug prosecutions are down 10% in 2025 — their lowest level in decades — as the Trump administration shifts agents to immigration enforcement. Reuters gathered dockets from nearly 2 million federal criminal cases since the late 1990s to measure the extent of the Trump administration’s pullback. 
 
🔗 Read the full report at the link in bio.

An Israeli armored personnel carrier manoeuvres on the Israeli side of the Israel-Gaza border, September 29, 2025.  
 
Israeli tanks thrust closer to the heart of Gaza City in the hours before Donald Trump was due to host Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House, where the U.S. president has promised “SOMETHING SPECIAL” in his latest bid to end the war.  
 
After nearly two years of failed diplomacy, Washington presented a 21-point plan to Arab and Muslim states last week that calls for a permanent ceasefire and the release of remaining hostages, and Trump said he believed a deal was close. 
 
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Amir Cohen

Nuns from the Dominican Sisters of St. Cecilia are teaching children and adults in Scotland about the Catholic faith.
 
A US-based religious order were invited to live at Greyfriars Convent in Elgin, northeast Scotland, which dates back to 1479, in 2013, after a previous group of nuns left as their numbers dwindled. 
 
🔗 Read more at the link in bio. 📸 @hannahmckay88

Migrants wade through the sea from the beach of Petit-Fort-Philippe in Gravelines, near Calais, France, to attempt to board an inflatable dinghy to cross the English Channel to reach Britain, September 27, 2025. 📷 @abdul_saboor079

The Israeli military said it targeted a Hamas camera in an August strike on a Gaza hospital, but a Reuters investigation found the device belonged to the news agency and had long been used by one of its own journalists, Hussam al-Masri, who was killed in the strike. An Israeli military official now says troops fired without required approval. 
 
The five journalists who died in the strike are among some 200 killed by Israel that it has yet to fully explain.
 
🔗 Read the visual investigation at our link in bio.

A humanitarian crisis afflicts Ebeye, a community the U.S. created in the 1950s, and whose labor it depends on to run an army base on the island of Kwajalein that America calls a ‘vital national asset.’ Diabetes is rampant and fish in the waters around the tiny Pacific island are contaminated.
 
The commander of Kwajalein base says workers from Ebeye are ‘the backbone of our labor force.’ On Kwajalein, conditions are very different: Soldiers and contractors enjoy air-conditioned homes, public swimming pools, a nine-hole golf course and a bowling alley.
 
🔗 Read more at the link in bio

A U.S. immigration officer shoving a woman in a New York City courthouse to the floor. Protesters dispersed with tear gas outside a Chicago detention center. A woman injured during an arrest in the Boston area.
 
The incidents on Thursday and Friday highlight the growing tensions in major U.S. cities over President Donald Trump's aggressive immigration crackdown days after a shooting targeting an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Dallas left one detainee dead and two others seriously wounded.
 
Milagros Barreto, a worker advocate with La Colaborativa, a pro-immigrant group in Chelsea, Massachusetts, said she witnessed ICE throw a Guatemalan woman to the ground on Friday despite her being a permanent resident.
 
Reuters captured images of the woman on the ground, her hands pinned behind her back, being detained by federal agents while her son stood nearby crying. Further images showed her in distress as she was taken away by emergency responders.
 
🔗 Read more at the link in bio. 📷 @brian_photog

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, speaking at the United Nations on Friday vowed to continue Israel's war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip and told the hostages still held by the Palestinian militants they were not forgotten. 

Israel's military response has killed more than 65,000 people in Gaza, according to local health officials, and left much of the territory in ruins.

Scores of delegates exited the hall as Netanyahu took the stage while attendees in the balcony rose to their feet to give him a standing ovation. 

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @jeenahmoon @zanderavery @caitochs

Hundreds of Orthodox priests from Moldova received an offer that seemed too good to be true — an all-expenses-paid pilgrimage to Moscow to visit some of the most significant sites of their religion. 
 
The catch? The priests received bank cards and cash, and in return were told to set up social media channels to warn their flocks about the dangers of the pro-Western government’s pursuit of closer European integration ahead of the national election.
 
🔗 Read the special report at our link in bio.

Surveillance footage from a Hong Kong restaurant shows water crash into the establishment during Super Typhoon Ragasa on September 24.
 
Hong Kong and several coastal cities in China’s southern Guangdong province reopened businesses, transportation services and schools on September 25 after the world’s most powerful tropical cyclone this year lashed the region.
 
More than 100 people were injured in Hong Kong, where authorities imposed the highest typhoon signal 10. Hong Kong resumed flights out of its international airport after a 36-hour suspension.
 
🔗 “Higher than we expected”: Read what business owners had to say about the floodwaters at our link in bio.

Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy left court with his wife Carla Bruni-Sarkozy after he was sentenced to five years in jail in Paris, France, September 25, 2025. Sarkozy was found guilty of criminal conspiracy over dealings with Libya, an unprecedented punishment for a leading French political figure. 
 
The sentence was harsher than many expected, and a first in modern French political history. Sarkozy, who was president between 2007-2012, will spend time in jail even if he appeals the ruling.  🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @stephanielecocq88

Denmark’s Aalborg airport, used for commercial and military flights, was closed due to drones in its airspace, police said early on September 25, two days after similar sightings shut Copenhagen’s main airport and raised European security concerns. Eyewitness Morten Skov told Reuters he saw green blinking lights coming from the west of the airport late on September 24.

A tree lies toppled by Super Typhoon Ragasa’s fierce winds in Hong Kong, September 24, 2025. 

The world's most powerful tropical cyclone this year struck the southern Chinese city of Yangjiang on Wednesday after killing 17 people in Taiwan and lashing Hong Kong with ferocious winds and heavy rains.

The typhoon was tracking toward Maoming, one of China's biggest oil refining cities, in Guangdong province.

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @Tyrone_Siu

Jimmy Kimmel struggled at times to get the words out during his monologue as he returned to late-night television on September 23 following a nearly weeklong suspension over his on-air remarks about the man accused of assassinating conservative activist Charlie Kirk that drew the ire of the Trump administration.
 
#kimmel #TV #charliekirk #jimmykimmel #abc

The United Nations believes it has solved the mystery of why an escalator abruptly stopped shortly after U.S. President Donald Trump stepped onto it on Tuesday - his videographer may have accidentally triggered a safety mechanism.
Trump jokingly complained about the incident during his speech to world leaders earlier on Tuesday after the teleprompter also didn't work.
“These are the two things I got from the United Nations - a bad escalator and a bad teleprompter," he told the 193-member assembly, to some laughter. 

🔗 Read the full story at our link in bio. 📷 @kyliecooperphoto

“What is the purpose of the United Nations?”: Trump told world leaders their countries are “going to hell” in a combative United Nations General Assembly speech that began with a broken teleprompter.
 
Trump argued for lower levels of global migration and urged a turn away from climate change policies in a wide-ranging address that leveled scathing criticism of world leaders.
 
The 56-minute speech was a rebuke to the world body and a return to form for Trump, who routinely bashed the U.N. during his first term as president. 
 
🔗 Read the full story at our link in bio.
U.S. Marines run alongside a jogger during a morning training session in Washington, D.C., September 23, 2025. 📷 @dannybcrril

French President Emmanuel Macron called U.S. President Donald Trump after being stopped at a New York street blocked off for his U.S. counterpart's motorcade during the United Nations General Assembly.
 
🔗 “Guess what?” — read about Macron’s call to Trump at our link in bio.

Britain, Canada, Australia and Portugal announced over the weekend the recognition of a Palestinian state and several more are expected to do so at a summit at the U.N. on the two-state solution — a move Israel says will undermine the prospects of a peaceful ending to the war in Gaza.
 
While the summit in New York could boost the morale of Palestinians, it is not expected to deliver change on the ground, where the most far-right government in Israel’s history has declared there will be no Palestinian state as it pushes on with its fight against militant group Hamas.
 
🔗 Read a breakdown from UN bureau chief Michelle Nichols on what’s at stake at our link in bio.

Several world leaders are expected to formally recognize a Palestinian state at a summit convened by France and Saudi Arabia, despite Israel’s opposition, which views this move as undermining peace prospects in Gaza.
 
Israel and the United States will not participate in the summit, with Israel’s U.N. Ambassador Danny Danon describing it as a ‘circus.’ The summit aims to boost Palestinian morale but is not expected to change the situation on the ground. 🔗 Read more at the link in bio

A Palestinian flag is raised during a ceremony the day after the British government announced the country’s formal recognition of a Palestinian state, at the Palestinian mission’s headquarters in London on September 22, 2025.
 
Several world leaders are expected to formally recognize a Palestinian state at a summit convened by France and Saudi Arabia, a move Israel says will undermine the prospects of a peaceful ending to the war in Gaza. While the summit in New York could boost the morale of Palestinians, it is not expected to deliver change on the ground, where Israel has declared there will be no Palestinian state as it pushes on with its fight against militant group Hamas.
 
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @TobyMelville

In an emotional moment during the memorial service of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, who was assassinated earlier this month, his widow, Erika Kirk, broke down in tears as she told the crowd she forgives the alleged shooter.
 
#erikakirk #charliekirk #memorial #shooter #arizona

Some called Charlie Kirk a modern martyr. Others said his death was a pivotal moment for the U.S.
The potent blend of politics and religion that captivated the Sunday afternoon memorial service for the slain conservative activist left little doubt that Kirk’s death had elevated him to iconic status for the American right.
The event at State Farm Stadium outside Phoenix drew some of the most powerful political and religious voices in the country, led by President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance, Kirk’s widow Erika and many others. Its size, intensity and patriotic pageantry eclipsed many of Trump’s own campaign rallies last year. 🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 @carlosabarria @brian_photog @callaghan_ohare @orr_photo @caitlin_oh @danielcolepares

A displaced Palestinian girl, one of many fleeing northern Gaza due to an Israeli military operation, rides southward on a vehicle carrying wooden doors and other items in the central Gaza Strip, September 21, 2025, after Israeli forces ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to the south.
Britain said on Sunday it was recognizing a Palestinian state after Israel failed to meet conditions including a ceasefire in the nearly two-year-old Gaza war.
Canada and Australia also recognized a Palestinian state on Sunday and other countries are expected to do so this week at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
"Today, to revive the hope of peace for the Palestinians and Israelis, and a two-state solution, the United Kingdom formally recognises the State of Palestine," Prime Minister Keir Starmer said on X.
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Mahmoud Issa

Film and TV writers held a free-speech demonstration in New York on September 19 to protest Disney’s suspension of talk-show host Jimmy Kimmel and President Donald Trump’s efforts to punish broadcasters who speak ill of him or his murdered ally, right-wing activist Charlie Kirk.
 
ABC, the television network owned by Disney, indefinitely suspended “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” this week after Kimmel discussed Kirk and mocked the president during his opening monologue on September 15.
Some conservatives were outraged by the monologue.
 
The Trump-appointed head of the Federal Communications Commission, Brendan Carr, threatened regulatory action, alarming Democrats and civil rights groups who accused the Trump administration of unconstitutional efforts to censor critical media. The owners of dozens of ABC-affiliated local TV networks said they would not carry the show until Kimmel apologized to Kirk’s family.
 
#jimmykimmel #charliekirk #shooting #trump #fcc

A Reuters journey shows Syria’s Euphrates River is a simmering frontline

Syria is hardening into two main parts, controlled by rival armed groups. The Euphrates River divides them. A Reuters journey over hundreds of miles shows how tensions are heating up between the Islamist factions that dominate the government and Kurdish militants who hold the country’s oil wealth and hydroelectric dams. Correspondent John Davison explains what the team found along an unmarked frontline in the struggle for the new Syria.
🔗 Read the full Reuters investigation at our link in bio.

Barbie Reynolds is embraced by her daughter Sarah Entwistle after disembarking from a plane in Doha, Qatar, September 19, 2025.

Reynolds, 76, and her husband Peter, 80, arrived in Qatar from Afghanistan after the British couple were freed from eight months in Taliban captivity.
 
Family members said they had been concerned for the health of the couple, who ran a charity in Afghanistan where they had lived for 18 years, staying on after the Taliban returned to power in 2021. 

🔗 Read more at our link in bio. 📷 @Ibraheem_Abu_Mustafa  #reuters #reutersphotos #Afghanistan #release

U.S. President Trump praised ABC’s decision to pull “Jimmy Kimmel Live” off the air. He said during a news conference with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer that the late-night television host said “a horrible thing” about assassinated political activist Charlie Kirk and also had “bad ratings.”

🔗 Live updates from Trump’s UK visit at our link in bio. 
 
#trump #jimmykimmel #abc #suspension #charliekirk

French riot police use tear gas on protesters at a demonstration in Paris, France, as part of a day of nationwide strikes and protests against the government and cuts in the next budget, with supporters of the "Bloquons Tout" (Let's Block Everything) movement, September 18, 2025.

Hundreds of thousands took part in the protests, unions said, urging President Emmanuel Macron and his new Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to acknowledge their anger and the scrap looming budget cuts. 

🔗 Read more at our link in bio. 📷 @TNicholsonphoto
 #France #reuters #reutersphotos #protests

In a matter of weeks, U.S. Health Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr. has restricted eligibility for COVID shots, prompted the ouster of the country’s top public-health official, amplified federal support for states’ vaccine exemptions, dismantled the process for reviewing vaccine recommendations, and expanded a national vaccine advisory board with experts who share his opposition to COVID shots.
 
The most consequential change so far may come within days. On September 18 and 19, the vaccine advisory board is due to vote on potential changes to the immunizations recommended for U.S. children. 
 
🔗 Read more at our link in bio.

Thai soldiers and riot police officers confronted Cambodian people in a disputed village along the Thailand-Cambodia border on September 17, 2025. Thai police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at Cambodian civilians in a disputed border area on Wednesday, authorities in both countries said, the most significant escalation since they declared a ceasefire to end a deadly five-day conflict in July. 

At least 23 Cambodians were injured in the incident, according to Cambodian authorities, while Thailand’s military said an unspecified number of Thai officials had also sustained injuries. 

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Royal Thai Army #thailand #cambodia #reuters #reutersphotos

On September 17, 2024, thousands of pagers carried by members of Lebanese armed group Hezbollah exploded simultaneously, followed the next day by booby-trapped walkie-talkies.
 
The exploding pagers and walkie-talkies were the opening salvo of a devastating war between Israel and Hezbollah that left the group badly weakened and swathes of Lebanon in ruins.
 
Thirty-nine people were killed and more than 3,400 wounded, including children and other civilians who were near the devices when they blew up but were not members of the Iran-backed group.
 
A Lebanese member of parliament and eye surgeon who conducted dozens of operations on those affected, said that some of the cases would have to receive lifelong treatment.
 
🔗 Read more about their stories at our link in bio.

U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told former CDC Director Susan Monarez two days before her August firing that the childhood vaccination schedule would change in September, Monarez told a Senate panel.
 
Kennedy asked her to commit to approving the changes before reviewing scientific evidence and said there is no evidence supporting the current schedule, Monarez said.
 
🔗 Read more about the controversy at our link in bio.
 
#monarez #rfkjr #cdc #vaccines #politicization #publichealth

Britain’s King Charles and U.S. President Donald Trump sit in a carriage during a procession through Windsor Castle, in Windsor, September 17, 2025.
 
The U.S. president’s historic second state visit to Britain began with unprecedented pomp, intense security, technology investments and planned protests. Trump and his wife Melania arrived at Windsor Castle, the oldest and largest inhabited castle in the world and family home to British monarchs for almost 1,000 years, where the royal red carpet treatment includes a carriage procession, gun salutes, a military flypast and lavish banquet. 🔗 Follow our live coverage of Trump’s visit at our link in bio. 📷 @TobyMelville #trump #kingcharles #royals #windsor #reuters #reutersphotos

Prosecutors in Utah charged Tyler Robinson, 22, with killing right-wing activist Charlie Kirk with a long-range rifle shot on September 10. Gavino Garay brings you the latest.
 
🔗 Read our factbox with everything you need to know about the case against Robinson at our link in bio.
 
#charliekirk #charliekirkshooting #spencercox #corybooker #utahshooting

A New York state judge dismissed two terrorism-related counts against Luigi Mangione over the December 2024 killing of health insurance executive Brian Thompson, though the 27-year-old remains charged with second-degree murder and eight other criminal counts in the case.
 
🔗 Read about the other charges he faces, along with a separate federal indictment, at our link in bio.
 
#court#unitedhealthcare#newyork#luigimangione#brianthompson

Displaced Palestinians flee northern Gaza after Israeli forces ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to the south, in the central Gaza Strip, September 16, 2025. Israel unleashed a long-threatened ground assault on Gaza City on Tuesday as Palestinians there described the most intense bombardment they had faced in two years of war.
 
An Israel Defence Forces official said ground troops were moving deeper into the enclave's main city, and that the number of soldiers would rise in coming days to confront up to 3,000 Hamas combatants the IDF believes are still in the city. 
 
🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Mahmoud Issa #Gaza #Israel #reuters #reutersphotos #GazaCity

The mother of Rashik Khatiwada, 23, who died in last week's anti-corruption protests that toppled the government, mourns during cremation rituals at the premises of Pashupatinath temple, along the bank of Bagmati river, in Kathmandu, Nepal, September 16, 2025.
 
🔗 Read more about Nepal's deadly protests at our link in bio. 📷 @Navesh.Chitrakar #Nepal #reuters #reutersphotos #protests

Displaced Palestinians, fleeing northern Gaza due to an Israeli military operation, move southward in the central Gaza Strip, September 15, 2025, after Israeli forces ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to the south. 

Israel destroyed a score of buildings in Gaza City, killing at least 16 Palestinians, local health authorities said on Monday, while U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio discussed the war with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem.

Rubio’s visit coincided with an emergency summit in Qatar of Arab and Islamic states, some of them close U.S. allies, convened in response to Israel’s attack last week on leaders of Hamas who reside in the Gulf state.

🔗 Read the latest news at our link in bio. 📷 Mahmoud Issa #gaza #israel #gazacity #reuters #reutersphotos

Abu Dakha escaped Gaza to Europe on a jet ski. He documented his story through videos, photographs and audio files, which he shared with Reuters. Reuters also interviewed him and his travel companions upon their arrival in Italy, and their relatives in the Gaza Strip. 🔗 Read the full story at the link in bio.

Stephen Colbert accepts the award for Outstanding Variety Talk Series award for “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert” at the 77th Primetime Emmy Awards in Los Angeles, California, September 14, 2025. 📷 @msk8blake #colbert #stephencolbert #emmys #emmy #reuters #reutersphotos

Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro leaves house arrest and arrives at a hospital to undergo a skin surgery procedure in Brasilia, Brazil, September 14, 2025. 
Bolsonaro was sentenced on Thursday to 27 years and three months in prison hours after being convicted of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election, dealing a powerful rebuke to one of the world's most prominent far-right populist leaders. 

🔗 Read more at our link in bio. 📷 @Adrianofoto #Brazil #reuters #reutersphotos #Bolsonaro #Brazil

A young Utah man suspected of killing conservative activist Charlie Kirk at a university in the city of Orem was in custody on September 12, Utah Governor Spencer Cox told reporters.
 
The suspect, identified as Tyler Robinson, had confessed to a family friend — or “implied that he had committed the murder” to that friend — and that person in turn had contacted the Washington County sheriff’s office on September 11.

Belarus freed 52 prisoners including an EU employee after an appeal from U.S. President Donald Trump, as Washington and Minsk flirted with a rapprochement that many European leaders have viewed sceptically.

U.S. right-wing activist and commentator Charlie Kirk was shot on Wednesday at an event at Utah Valley University in Orem, Utah, and a suspect was in custody.
Kirk, 31, is an influential ally of President Donald Trump and co-founder of Turning Point USA, the largest conservative youth organization in the country. He was taken to a hospital, Fox News reported.

A member of the Polish Army inspects a damaged house in Wyryki, Lublin Voivodeship, Poland, after Russian drones violated Polish airspace during an attack on Ukraine and some were shot down by Poland on September 10, 2025. 
 
Poland shot down the drones with the backing of military aircraft from its NATO allies, the first time a member of the Western military alliance is known to have fired shots during Russia’s war in Ukraine.
 
Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk told parliament it was “the closest we have been to open conflict since World War Two,” although he also said he had “no reason to believe we’re on the brink of war.”

Russia is preparing for the return of hundreds of thousands of soldiers, including pardoned convicts, from the war in Ukraine. 
 
The challenges of managing returning veterans aren't unique to Russia. A "substantial minority" of the roughly 2.7 million Americans who served in Vietnam, for example, suffered psychological and life-adjustment problems, according to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. 
 
A key difference about the war in Ukraine from many conflicts, though, is the deployment of convicts on the battlefield. Data from the Russian prison service and Ukraine's intelligence services suggest that Russia has recruited 120,000-180,000 convicts to fight in Ukraine since 2022. 
 
🔗 Read more at the link in bio.

Lachlan Murdoch has cemented control of the Murdoch family media empire, which includes Fox News and The Wall Street Journal, following a family agreement that resolves succession questions. 
 
The agreement ends a family brawl over who will control one of the most high-profile global media groups and puts to rest questions of succession within the Murdoch family after its patriarch’s death.

An Afghan man helps an injured person after a deadly magnitude-6 earthquake that struck around midnight, as others take refuge in a field in Dara Mazar, in Kunar province, Afghanistan, September 1, 2025. 

One of Afghanistan's worst earthquakes killed more than 800 people and injured at least 2,800, authorities said on Monday, as helicopters ferried the wounded to hospital after they were plucked from the rubble of homes being combed for survivors.

The disaster is set to further stretch the resources of the war-torn nation's Taliban administration, already grappling with humanitarian crises, from a sharp drop in aid to the pushback of hundreds of thousands of Afghans by neighboring countries.

The southern Ukrainian city of Enerhodar was once a thriving hub that provided electricity across the country.

People visit a beauty salon that was damaged in a Russian missile and drone strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, August 28, 2025. 
 
Russia pounded Ukraine with deadly missiles and drone strikes early on Thursday in a sweeping attack that President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said was Moscow's answer to diplomatic efforts to end its war.
